data.text: How Do You Deal with the Rain when Touring / Bikepacking?

How do you deal with the rain? I'm planning a couple of trips to Norway and Scotland, both very wet places. I have a Gore ShakeDry jacket and waterproof socks. I also have lightweight Outdoor Research waterproof trousers. Is there anything else you recommend? I have a treated down quilt, but it always gets wet when it rains hard enough and I worry if the sun doesn't come out the next day (which I have yet to face). Do you wash your bibs when it rains day in day out? Is it better to wash them and wear them wet? What about wet feet?

Maybe a stupid question, but how does your quilt get wet? When I'm bikepacking my quilt is either in my drybag strapped to my bike, or inside my tent (which shouldnt be getting too wet on the inside no matter how hard it rains, otherwise you need a new shelter for such wet conditions). As for wet feet, I have not had the chance to test them in wet conditions but I have bike-specific gaiters to cover my feet and calves. I use flats, so I can wear them all day while biking and setting up camp. There's two ways to deal with rain for every piece of gear. You can either use drybags, ziplocks and other methods to keep something dry that must stay dry at all costs (phone, electronics, etc.) or pick gear which won't ruin your day if it gets wet (wool vs. cotton since it retains heat while wet, polyester/nylon clothes that dry fast, etc.). You can't keep everything dry in rainy conditions, so it's just about protecting the stuff that REALLY has to stay dry and minimizing the impact of soaked gear on your experience otherwise. Personally I would make an effort to make sure my quilt stays dry because trying to sleep in a soggy quilt sounds awful but everyone has their own personal comfort zones/tolerances for that kind of thing.

data.text: Typically when it's wet where I ride it's warm. I use synthetic quilts with my hammock this time of year. I wear clothes that dry quickly and plan on getting wet. data.author: Pavel Klinov

data.text: Hate to break it to you, but there is no dry in these situations, just warm. I live in the PNW between the mainland and the Olympic Peninsula and one thing I do a lot of is bikepack/camp in the rain and cold. I have a three-pronged approach. 1) Start with a lightweight summer kit. 2) Add warm layers - expedition weight arm/leg warmers, light weight vest, midweight gloves. 3) Add rain/wind gear - Gore shakedry jacket (I like the trail running version), light weight rain pants (I added brass grommets to the bottom of each leg and tied on cordage to act as stirrups). light weight waterproof over-mitts, and waterproof socks (I like the thin SealSkinz midcalf ones) to fit over your thin wool summer socks. I too use a treated down quilt and while it does get damp overtime, it has never gotten to the point of soaking. I do carry SOL emergency bivy that I cut open and made into a blanket to throw over my bag in case things get too cold. As far as bibs are concerned, I carry an additional par and wash/switch every day/other day. I have a smallish polypro camp towel that I use to wring out most of the moisture after washing and then store the clean bibs in the towel and wring it out a few times during the day. Wet feet are no joke! Carry a pair of wool socks to sleep in (nothing else, just sleeping). Clean your feet every night with wet wipes and let them dry before putting on your dry sleeping socks. Lastly, something like a Patagonia Nano-Puff jacket with a hood is worth its weight in gold. Keep it accessible (but in a waterproof bag) to throw on when you stop (I sized up on my ShakeDry jacket so that it can be worn over a puffy coat if necessary). Whew! I hope some of this rambling helps and enjoy your trips!! You'll have an awesome time üôÇ

data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: ok I have a few questions since you seem the most knowledgeable here. Let me start with sleeping gear. You mention having a dry pair of wool socks for sleeping in, and cleaning your feet before wearing them. Sounds great, as I'm guessing that ensures your feet are dry at least while sleeping. What about when you need to leave your shelter to pee for example? The socks would get wet then. What do you do with a wet tent if there's no break in the clouds? Do you just keep it packed wet? Where do you store your wet clothes at camp? I currently store them inside my tent, but I now realise that is very likely contributing to the condensation. And then more of a mental question. How do you muster up the will to pack up when it's pouring rain? So far I've had the luxury of being able to monitor the weather forecast and wait out the worst of it.
